Award.AwardTitle: Phylogenomics of polyploidy in the Brassicales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving crop plants can be accomplished by creating hybrids. Some hybrids, like mules, are sterile, because the parents have different chromosome numbers. In plants, some sterile hybrids can become fertile when their chromosome number is doubled, a process called polyploidy. Many important crop plants, such as alfalfa, cotton, potato, and wheat are recent polyploids while others, such as maize, soybean, and cabbage, retain the vestiges of ancient polyploid events. This project will investigate how polyploidy can give rise to novel traits, such as the resistance to insects, in the order Brassicales (broccoli, mustards, capers, papaya, and relatives). The investigators of this project have developed new phylogenomics methods that allow one to understand the evolutionary history of how species are related while simultaneously determining whether or not they are polyploid.

At a time when rapid global changes are placing unprecedented pressure on plants in agricultural and natural landscapes, it is imperative that scientists think beyond a single discipline. Phylogenomics has emerged as an interdisciplinary approach in the biological sciences; however, there are few opportunities to learn the genomic and bioinformatics tools becoming required in biology. To address this gap, this project will develop modules for undergraduate courses; create an interdisciplinary research environment that uses computational methods; and engage in outreach to systematic biologists by annual workshops. All research proposed here involves recruiting and mentoring students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  Where do new traits come from?  The genetic basis of some traits can be traced to single base changes in the genetic code, while other novel traits are associated with the duplications that range in size from single genes to entire genomes. Whole genome duplications (or polyploid events) are major mutations that have long been recognized as a major evolutionary force as every gene and pathway is simultaneously duplicated – allowing for large scale evolutionary tinkering.  This project tested competing hypotheses about whether or not these duplications are associated with new traits or lead to an increase in diversification of species or functions. A striking correlation was found between ancient polyploidy, species diversification, and a resistance to caterpillar feeding in the mustard plant family.  Nearly 90 million years ago the ancestors of the plant order Brassicales (mustards, capers, and papaya) evolved chemicals (called glucosinolates) that act as a chemical defense against caterpillars. But within 10 million years the caterpillars developed the ability to detoxify the glucosinates, so that a previously toxic compound became an attractant and they could continue feeding on the plant. The situation escalated in an evolutionary arms race with the plants making stronger defensive chemicals, which again the caterpillars had to overcome. Key innovations in both the plants and caterpillars were associated with duplications of both single genes and whole genomes.  The studies support the hypothesis that co-evolution between plants and insects drives biodiversity. They also explain the origin of tasty flavors of plants such as mustard, wasabi and horseradish that are so enjoyed by humans.

Broader Impacts.  At a time when rapid global changes are placing unprecedented pressure on plants in agricultural and natural landscapes, it is imperative that scientists think beyond a single discipline or approach.  Phylogenomics has emerged as an interdisciplinary approach in the biological sciences.  However, few training opportunities in phylogenomics are available for students or researchers because it is at the intersection of two rapidly developing fields, genomics and informatics. Nonetheless, exposure to interdisciplinary problem solving is critical to training the next generation of scientists. In this project, graduate and undergraduate students were trained in new wet-lab and dry-lab methods, ranging from genome sequencing to bioinformatics.
